commit.message:
Some further improvements to tracers against invisible players

The approach of the previous commit could very slightly wrong in some
cases, since hit_count can be incremented even by actions that might not
call tracer_affect_player() (for instance, explosions prior to their
explode phase). Since what we're actually concerned about is that monsters
don't believe they can hit the player repeatedly - overpowering all
friendly fire concerns - put the check for duplicate player hits in the
tracer itself.

In addition, change fuzzing behavior so that monsters will not believe the
player could be standing in a wall or on top of their own allies. While
there are probably multiple bugs this results in, one I am specifically
aware of is that monsters will stop casting healing/buffing beams near an
invisible player, since they think the player is standing on top of all
their allies.

Fix more friendly fire issues with penetrating beams against unseen players

Tracers with invisible players count the player in every square within
2 of their actual position, to allow firing at the wrong square when
the monster targets the wrong square. This leads to penetrating tracers
double counting the player for the purposes of friendly fire
calculations (and would lead to more than that, except that no beam can
hit anything thrice).

We fix this by not counting more hits on the player than bounces+1.
This is a bit crude, but works in all cases except a bouncing beam
that misses the player on the first pass and hits twice thereafter,
which seems likely rare.

Remove fuzz_invis_tracer

This updated the tracer target. This did almost nothing; the target is
not persisted because undo_tracer reverts the update, and the ray
being traced was not changed. There's a possibility it was having
more subtle effects, like changing when the ray stopped or whether
it thinks it passed its target, but if so these were almost certainly
unintended and unreliable, so it's hard to see how they could matter.

We keep the other thing this function did, which was check whether
the monster is targetting somewhere near the player.

Make javelins pierce in monster tracers

This was causing problems like:
- Not firing through a monster blocking the player, even if worth it
- Not caring about hitting monsters behind the player
- Complicated stuff when the player was invisible, including very
surprising levels of friendly fire.

[Committer's note: Removed the last remaining use of
setup_monster_throw_beam() (Dith shadow mimic) which could use
setup_missile_beam() just as easily.]

Fix many talisman properties not scaling between integer skill levels

Apparently divided_scaling() was meant to be used in most cases rather than
scaling_value(). I think that's a little confusing (and also there were
very few cases that *didn't* want to divided the scaled value after
calculating), so I have refactored slightly.

scaling_value() should now be the only function any form needs to interact
with directly, and in the rare cases you want to divide something by
something other than the default 100 scale, that is what you specify.

Fix dragon form breath damage being wrong in the talisman preview

If you weren't actually in dragon form at the time, it would give
incredibly low numbers. (This is because draconian_breath_power() used -1
to denote 'use current form power' and since cd48741 the current skill
level of talisman previews also uses that.

Fix preview of talisman attributes between integer skill levels.

Between integer values of shapeshifting, these were wrong - e.g.
showing -10% HP until hitting minimum shapeshifting, when in fact
things are much more continuous than that.
Fix the build

Rework choosing tiles for items

Normal, shiny, runed, glowing and randart versions of an item can all
get their own tile. For an item with all variations we would define a
tile group with 5 tiles in it for the item and then use tile 1 for
normal, tile 2 for shiny, tile 3 for runed, tile 4 for glowing and tile
5 for randart. We could also only put 4 tiles in the group in which case
shiny and runed items would get the same tile, or 3 tile in the group so
that shiny, runed and glowing items all get the same tile, or 2 items in
the group so that all non-normal items get the same tile, or 1 item in
the group so that all items get the same tile.

This usually worked well, however, there were a couple problems. First,
for an item to with one tile for artifacts and one tile for everything
else, you would either add special case tile picking code for this item
or duplicate its non-artifact tile so that its tile group consisted of
its non-artifact tile, its non-artifact tile duplicate, and then its
artifact tile. Secondly, some items have multiple tiles for normal
versions of the item or for artifacts etc. This would require special
casing the item tile picking code to handle the item. All this special
casing resulted in item tile picking being a hard to modify mess.

We have a very similar problem when picking tiles for walls and floors
of different colours and the solution to that problem can easily be
used to fix our item tile picking mess by replacing colour (e.g. red,
green, etc) with enchanted level (e.g. shiny, randart etc).

Rework how equipped tiles are specified for artifacts

In art-data.txt we were specifying the file for the equipped tile of
artifiacts. The tiles are defined in dc-player.txt and we need the name
of the tile so we were searching through dc-player.txt to try and find
a tile that had the given file. However, parsing tile definition files
isn't easy and the way we were doing it put some very strong
restrictions on how tiles are defined in dc-player.txt making it hard to
change. It also makes more sense for the tile names to be used in
art-data.txt as a tile can be made from modifying the file it was loaded
from or even compositing multiple files together.

Rename an obsoletely-named variable: mr -> wl.

Since magic resistance has been willpower for ages.

Fix encounter messages for multiple dancing weapons (Flugkiller)

If the player encountered multiple dancing weapons and at least one other
type of monster at the same time, you would get a message like:
"You encounter 4 dancing weapons and a deep elf knight. There is . There
is . There is . There is ."

Now it should properly say what they actually are.

Improve handling of permanent creations of summoned/charmed monsters

There has been a recurring class of bug over the years where permanent
monsters made as part of another monster behavior (for instance, protean
progenitor death spawns or mangrove fauna) would not properly inherit some
of the properties of their parents. Namely, if you charmed the original, or
summoned it (perhaps by a scroll), any monster made be it would be
permanently friendly.

There was bespoke handling for a subset of these cases for some monsters,
but this was fairly incomplete (and different from monster to monster).

This commit adds a simple, unified way to inherit the charm and summon
status of a given 'parent' monster. It then revises code for The Royal
Jelly, protean progenitors, shambling mangroves, and bennu revival to use
this (fixing an assortment of bugs in the process).

It is possible there are other cases which should make use of it that I
have overlooked, but they would now be simple to address once pointed out.

Make Gloom silent

A thematically appropriate very minor buff (now that its BEAM_VISUAL isn't
unexpectedly waking monsters up on its own....)

It was already pretty quiet and there's no reason to cast this on a monster
which is already asleep, but in some situations there may be other sleeping
monsters nearby while the player is fighting something which is awake and
this allows the possibility of being slightly stealthier about it than
before.

Make BEAM_VISUAL imply affects_nothing and refactor slightly

There is technically still a slight difference between using BEAM_VISUAL
and using any other beam with affects_nothing = true, which is that the
latter can still print messages for observing a beam. I am not certain this
is used meaningfully anywhere, and future refactoring might eliminate one
of the two entirely.

Allow Mace of Variability to proc even when the melee target dies

This is an AoE effect and it's unclear why fatal blows should be unable to
trigger it.

Rework BEAM_CHAOS functionality

BEAM_CHAOS was rather odd in some ways and behaved like neither the weapon
brand nor the cloud. Since it applied its non-damaging effects entirely
via enchantment beams, it did not have access to the same set of secondary
effects as other sources of chaos, and unlike chaos weapons, did no damage
whatsoever if it rolled a status effect (though the hit message could
misleadingly suggest it did do damage!). Its status effects also checked
Will, unlike other chaos sources (but only when the player was the one
being hit!) and could roll irrelevant effects that other chaos sources
would exclude (such as Weakness on a monster with no attacks).

Now, it instead picks a random damage element, and then has a 50% chance of
applying a status effect on top of it, using the chaos_affects_actor() code
shared by other chaos sources. (The old chance of applying a status effect
was ~62%).

In addition, wording of the beam hits is changed so that it indicates what
element of damage is being done.

This is a relatively significant change to the damage componant of Awaken
Flesh, which should be a little more capable of actually doing something to
the player (and will be even more relevant for some 0.35 monster plans).

Remove impact damage from monster flame, noxious, and chaos cloud spells

This damage was very negligible and also sometimes weird: chaos cloud
impact damage followed different rules for its effects than the clouds
themselves did and noxious cloud impact could actually do poison damage
(which the clouds explicit never do). On top of this, it could print
somewhat confusing messages about 'missing' the player, regardless of
whether the player was now standing in a cloud or not.

These spells now function purely as cloud delivery and the direct beam
prints no additional messages about whether they 'hit' a target or not.

This comes with some additional tracer improvements where 0 damage cloud
beams will check the validity of their cloud against a monster target
(rather than assuming they will have no effect since they do no impact
damage)

Make monsters a little less foolish when aiming cloud spells

Monster cloud spells like fire crab breath have fairly randomized cloud
placement, and their tracers would consider a target in range if there was
ANY chance at all of a cloud being placed on their tile. However, this
chance might be quite low, semi-regularly resulting in monsters breathing
clouds at the player that never actually reach them.

This looks a bit foolish, so let's have them only take sure-fire shots.

Don't wake monsters with BEAM_VISUAL

These are intended for VFX and should not have a mechanical effect. (I
wonder if this is an old simulationist relic?)

In practice, it was difficult to have this matter, since most visual beams
are used by code that will also affect the monster in some way outside of
the beam anyway, but a few examples where this was possible included
pulling a corpse with Cigotuvi's Embrance or a monster being thrown over
their head with Throw Ally.

Tweak Awaken Flesh behaviour

It now prints the message about unleashing explosions *before* the
explosions happen, rather than after. It also transforms the piles of
flesh because causing damaging explosions (as another piece of insurance
against similar crashes to the one just fixed).

It also takes 'ownership' over any piles of flesh animated, whether they
were originally summoned by that specific fleshcrafter or not. (Prior to
this, fleshcrafters could animate non-aligned flesh, whose abominations
would continue to be non-aligned and possibly under someone else's summon
list.)

Tweak Bolt of Flesh behavior

Instead of creating its pile of flesh at the end of the full beam path
(which is often nowhere near the target it was actually aiming at), it now
places it immediately behind the last target hit.

In addition, the beam will shorten itself to specifically stop at this
point (and before hitting any allies). This means that some random ally in
the distance behind the player will no longer completely turn off a
fleshcrafter's spell set.

Add a method to return the position of the last actor a beam hit

(Or some number of steps beyond or before this.)

Will be used shortly for an adjustment to Bolt of Flesh, but likely has
other future uses.

Replace bound souls as a fineff instead of immediately

This lead to a rather obscure crash where a bound kobold fleshcrafter
killed a monster that the player had just used Bind Soul on, causing itself
to die in the middle of its own spell, dismissing the pile of flesh that
was about to transform and causing a divide-by-zero error when
change_monster_type tried to adjust its HP.

But this is probably not the only problem that can happen this way (a bound
soul killing another monster in the middle of a spell seems very
realistic), so it's probably safer to defer them dying a little.

Fix xv of off-screen monsters sometimes showing wildly high damage numbers

monster_info.slaying was not being properly marshalled or unmarshalled, so
if a remembered out-of-los monster was reloaded (possibly due to peeking at
another floor), it might show arbitrarily high damage values at random.

But at the same time, I found out that we also weren't marshalling monster
Will or See Invisible bonuses from gear properly and those would also
disappear when reloaded. This should no longe happen.

(At the same time, this removes a couple possibly-never-used string
parameters that were actually marshalled/unmarshalled to no effect.)

Remove an unneeded parameter

Monsters haven't had hidden randomized speed for quite a while, so there's
no need to have the option to hide it.

Dump piety info in wizard mode

The game is already spoiled, so there's no info leak, and it's helpful
to have this data to inspect for wizmode testing.
Refactor out a small code block

Log piety tables

Add logging for information related to piety.

This adds two tables to morgues:
- A tracker which records the piety gained/decayed/ lost at each piety
  rank, and what happens to the gains (e.g. spent on
  gifts/timeouts/actual piety).
- A tracker which records the frequency and piety from each conduct at
  each XL.

This will enable us to balance and then monitor potential changes like
simplifying piety formulae, removing piety decay, stopping gifts eating
piety, and fixing a bug with TSO.

We don't track gods who have funny relationships with piety, except to
log join and leave events.

The tables are enabled for trunk.
Add another rare graffiti author.
Add more orc names, and update the counts.
Add more vice names to artefacts.
Add another orcish name, and update the count.
Add more mythical animals to artefacts.

Fix cloud targeting for non-players

After 2322c751, the cloud targeter required having player LOS_NO_TRANS
for any potential cloud location, regardless of the agent. This doesn't
make sense for either monster agents or dungeon cloud generators. For
the latter, it meant that cloud generators wouldn't place clouds not on
their position until the player had LOS_NO_TRANS. This would give
players who could see cloud generators e.g. through glass a false
impression of how many clouds a generator would place.

This commit requires drops the LOS_NO_TRANS condition when there is no
agent. When there is an agent, the requirement is based on the agent's
LOS, instead of always on the player's.
Add another graffiti short saying.
Resort graffiti "happened reasons."
Add another rare graffiti author.
Add another graffiti duplicate option.
Fix wording of several graffiti rumours.
Expand graffiti "happened reasons."
Expand a graffiti fight option.

Make Teleport Other prefer not to cancel teleport

Fixes #3124

[Committer's note: Adjusted commit message.]
Properly use a canned message in Brom's.
Add "no available space" to canned messages.

Close lua states when reseting the game

Currently when a game is initialized (e.g. from the main menu), the CLua
initialization code for clua and dlua reruns but using the existing lua
states. A lot of this initialization code isn't appropriate to rerun on
a reused state. Things like setting metatables that already exist,
registering C functions that are already registered etc. With the switch
to Lua 5.4, this was resulting in crashes during reinitialization. This
commit has crawl close the lua states of clua/dlua before
reinitialization. This seems cleaner and more thorough rather than more
seletively reloading things on a more case by case basis and add little
overhead.
Properly pluralise "plasmodium" as "plasmodia."
Fix typos, wording and punctuation.

Changelog updates through 8a85f5c

Pressing enough to finally update again with the new weapon brands,
mutation revisions, and Slime changes alike.

(Thanks to DracoOmega for proofreading this.)

Make wizmode super-heal do more (tekkud).

It now heals flooding and diminished spells.
Add another orc name, and update the count.
Add another gizmo adjective.
Fix override warning.

Adjust artefacts' "chaos names."

Add Confusion, and rename Chaos to True Chaos so that it's less
confusable with the brand.

Fix all mutations being suppressed in the Abyss (tekkud)

Stupid logical operator precedence...

Clean up handling of some polymorphed uniques.

Use mons_is_mons_class() instead of looking at monster names, and add
mons_is_mons_species() to more easily check for a polymorphed Serpent of
Hell.

On a related note, monster names starting with "shaped" still have their
names handled specially in name_zombie_from_class(), just in case a vault
wants to place the zombified version of a polymorphed unique.

Remove remnants of polymorphed corpse handling.

Since monsters have reverted to their original forms upon death for
ages now, these are no longer needed.
Fix naming of the spectral Royal Jelly.

Fix hellfire mortar never actually moving (not_that_greg)

Accidentally broken by g6c3c90b89a though it is unclear to me now why it
was using a standard 'monster movement action' function instead of a
direct move_to call anyway, so now it just does that.

Use a cleaner method for checking TRJ's identity (hellmonk, gammafunk)

I got distracted in replicating the approach used by TRJ death code without
remembering that a better approach to this sort of problem had been
implemented in the interim.

Don't interrupt travel when the tide changes (Lici)

When Shoals tides changed terrain under the player's feet, it would
interrupt autoexplore. This obviously happened quite a lot, which was
mildly obnoxious.

I don't *think* there should be other cases of terrain changing under the
player's feet in more important ways at times autoexplore can actually
happen.

Prevent banishing The Royal Jelly

Banishing TRJ (often by accident) was always somewhat janky. It didn't
count as killing it for the purpose of opening the rune vault, either
forcing the player to track it down in the Abyss and kill it there or give
up on the rune entirely (or switch to Jiyva). But even if one went to the
Abyss, TRJ could still be lost forever - a single Abyss shift after
encountering it would remove it from the game altogether.

But with the new addition of slimy stairs, rather than simply blocking
access to the rune, banishing TRJ now locks the played into Slime:5,
sometimes with no other recourse but to join Jiyva. This places new urgency
on an old oddity.

Other alternatives were considered (such as opening an immediate portal to
the Abyss for the player to track TRJ, along with preventing them from
ever being lost), but fighting TRJ in the Abyss seems like such a mistake
in general that this would open happen to unaware players or by accident.
Ultimately, I think it's not worth preserving, and have opted for this
simple change instead. If anyone wants justification, assume that Jiyva is
keeping a special hold on their most important follower, so close to the
heart of their power.

Fix an odd slymdra-related crash

If you were aiming a wand of polymorph at a monster which could become a
slymdra, the game would crash.

Allow mutating Teleportitis even if you're currently a tree

Or wearing -tele gear.

It won't *do* anything immediately, but presumably the player will stop
being a tree again at some point.

Don't let formicids mutate Spatial Entanglement

They can technically trigger it via PoG, but that seems too marginal to be
worth allowing.

Don't give Devious charges for stabbing allies (rypofalem)

No matter how devious that may sound.

Refactor checks for whether actors are able to move under their own power

This renames player::is_motile() to player::cannot_move() (inverting its
logic) and implements cannot_move() as an actor method (checking both
stationary() and ENCH_BOUND for monsters). Many checks specifically for
ENCH_BOUND are replaced by this new method.

This also fixes a handful of other issues:
 -Monsters with ENCH_BOUND are allowed to be trampled (it only prevents
  volitional movement, and never any form of knockback).
 -Monsters with ENCH_BOUND can drag enemies towards them, so long as this
  action would not ask them to also move.
 -Slick slippers can make the player slip away from attacks even if the
  attacker cannot follow them.
 -Concussion weapons will no longer move their wielders forward if they
  cannot move.

This fixes #4975

Remove an unnecessary interaction between Wall Jump and formicid digging

I assume the digging clause dates back to when Wall Jump was triggered by
moving into walls, but at the moment it doesn't matter whether your
mandibles are extended or not, so there seems to be no need for this code.

Fix a crash with Concussion brand moving the player on top of a monster

This was possible if a monster was created at the same location as the
monster that was just knocked back, but before the follow fineff fired (for
example, by killing a protean progenitor and having one of its aspiring
flesh spawn in its old position).

Extend the Slime gem timer (Lici)

This was apparently already very tight, but with Slime made harder to dive,
was almost certainly too tight.

I am not sure if +300 turns is even sufficiently generous here, but we'll
watch and see.

Fix blazeheart cores being delayed by a turn in detonating (Zigmound)

Accidentally broken by g17f7e79a93 which caused energy to be deducted for
a melee attacks *after* the blazeheart golem's self-damage would cause it
to die, leaving its core one turn 'behind schedule' (previously the energy
deduction happened before it died).

Address this by simply making the core very fast. It should now be
impossible for the player to act so quickly that they get a second turn
before it blows up.
Expand a graffiti rumour.
Fix monster build warning.
Really, really fix tag_upgrade build?
Really fix tag_upgrade build?
Fix wording.
Fix typos.
Fix spelling.
Fix tag upgrade build

Tweak what can be created by Slimify

Instead of just azure jellies or acid blobs as the top-end spawns, all TRJ
spawns are now possible. (I think their absence had more to do with this
code not being edited in many, many years than any gameplay reason.)

In addition, we don't have to cap the top-end result at a slime creature if
the victim is over water, since rockslimes survive in deep water just fine!

Finally, per Darby's suggestion, add an easter egg where hydras become
slymdras.

Make all Slime branch natives acid-immune

This is immediately aimed at allowing plasmodia to operate freely around
anything in the branch, but will also be relevant when slimy walls are
changed in future to be able to corrode any non-resistant monsters.

Most jelly-genus monsters already had rCorr+++ (though there were a couple
exceptions, several of which probably weren't especially guessable), though
this also applies to eyeballs, none of whom previously resisted it. This
may seem slightly odd, but their connection to the Slime God was evidently
already so strong that merely worshipping makes them all friendly, so let's
just assume they all have Jiyva's blessing, if anybody asks.

Fix some odd behavior caused by monsters being distracted by their allies

Beams hitting monsters fire ME_ANNOY events, even when hostile monsters
are hitting their allies (and even when those hits are doing 0 damage). To
some degree this is necessary, since this is what controls breaking Daze,
Fear, or waking monsters up. However, there is a chain of other
consequences that can sometimes result in negative effects.

ME_ANNOY unconditionally sets that monster's foe to the source of that
event. handle_behavior() will later automatically set any monster whose
foe is an ally of theirs to MHITNOT. Then any of those monsters that are
BEH_SEEK + MHITNOT will automatically target the player if the player is
in LoS - or immediately start wandering if they are not (or if the monster
is an exploder).

This means, essentially, that any friendly fire among monsters will cause
all monsters out of LoS to immediately forget about the player - even if
they were immune to the attack. One of the most easy to observe examples
involves Lom Lobon, whose ball lightning explosions can give them rapid
amnesia (and are also likely to blow up on them while the player flees),
but this can happen under many other circumstances. It can also make ball
lightning themselves start wandering away while still in LoS.

Now, we no longer update a monster's foe if trying to set it to nothing or
an ally. This... hopefully doesn't have any other unforeseen negative
effects, but behavior code is such a snarl...

Make travel willing to path adjacent to slimy walls

Slimy walls aren't actually so dangerous that travel should consider them
impossible to walk near (they don't do anything at all outside combat!) and
in fact this regularly makes parts of Slime inaccessible to travel. This
became further hilighted when downstairs became able to place adjacent to
walls, where X> stopped working for them entirely.

Instead, consider slimy walls *expensive* to move near, so that autoexplore
will always prioritize nearby safe floor instead, but still be willing to
walk through it when there is no other choice. In practice, this means
enemies are almost always cleared out from the relevant areas first, so it
should not endanger the player, only convenience them.

Make Slime stairs slimy, and tweak layout

Slime is a branch almost exclusively dived through quickly. The lack of any
loot in the branch, combined with the disconnected layout frequently
placing down stairs in view of up stairs while giving little reason to
explore any other bubbles, meant that time spent anywhere but Slime:5 was
often very brief. Now that the monster pool has been greatly expanded, it
seems appropriate to ask players venturing here to engage with it a little
more.

At the same time, Slime had grown to be widely viewed as the 'easy' 3rd
rune option, and one goal of this batch of commits is to make that less
true - not necessarily to make it the 'hard' 3rd rune, but to bring it
closer to perceived parity with Vaults:5.

To that end (as well as to create a little more uniqueness in the branch),
stairs in Slime are now slimy: they can be taken downward but not travelled
back up again until The Royal Jelly is defeated (unless the player worships
Jiyva themselves). This is functionally a little different than hatches,
since alpha-striking TRJ and then fleeing *does* allow the player to leave
and regroup, and the path back up again is known, but otherwise makes each
new floor an isolated challenge at first.

In addition, the level generator no longer produces disconnected floors
(though it still uses layout_caves), hatches and shafts cannot generate,
down stairs are now allowed to spawn adjacent to slimy walls (up stairs
still cannot), and down stairs will always be placed at least 12 tiles away
from any up stair. All together, while the zone should still be
dive-friendly, one should no longer be able to trivially skip past most of
it so quickly, and levels before Slime:5 should matter more.

New Slime monster: Star Jelly (and consequent Void Ooze tweaks)

Star jellies (inspired by the real phenomenon) are mid-tier slime monsters
who unleash a trio of shooting stars (as from an orb of stardust) when
sufficiently damaged (on a long cooldown). To keep from it being frequently
correct to ignore them (since they are most immediately dangerous to the
player upon being damaged), they also have antimagic melee. This may also
help mildly counterbalance the fact that the shooting stars are most
dangerous if unleashed in melee.

In exchange, void oozes trade their own antimagic melee (which almost never
did anything in practice, due to its incredibly low base damage) for a new
AF_DIM that applies Diminished Spells to the target (and ignores AC).

Unlike the other new slime monsters, these are now a possible Royal Jelly
spawn as well, where their shooting star effect may provide some
interesting complications to traditional ?immo strats.

(I've also slightly lowered the max pursuit distance on shooting stars. I
suspect this will not have a very meaningful effect on the orb of stardust,
but should make it a little more possible to flee from them as a player.)

--------------------------

The star jelly vault distribution and tiles were done by regret-index.
 * The star jelly tiles combine rejected slime creature tiles by
   roctavian with Denzi's original jelly tile.
 * Vault distribution still is limited to Slime, one Depths vault, a
   few Sprints, and Ziggurats, where they replace scaling azure jelly
   placement in Slime floors to threaten mass conjurations spam.
   They also join Jiyva's wrath pool, to match the other TRJ spawns.

New Slime monster: Creeping plasmodium

These are motile slime mold colonies that can replicate themselves along
walls in a unique manner and inflict large scale AoE acid damage if allowed
to grow out of control.

Creeping Plasmodium are wall-only monsters that create Caustic Sporangium -
ball-lightning-esque monsters that detonate with a 7x7 acid explosion.
Uniquely, any wall tiles engulfed by this explosion will also spawn a
Nascent Plasmodium (as long as they are two tiles away from any existing
sporangium). These are lesser wall-bound monsters that cast acid ball -
less dangerous than their parents and unable to replicate, but still
contributing more and more ranged acid damage. They will all die when the
original plasmodium dies, but do not otherwise expire with time!

Not only do I feel that the monster design flavorfully captures the
uncontrollable spread of slime, but it also asks unique positioning on the
part of the player, since maneuvering the explosions to avoid walls can be
very important unless you're about to close in for the kill.

They are comparatively rare monsters in the branch and specifically do not
spawn naturally on Slime:5.

------------------------

The plasmodium vault distribution and tiles were done by regret-index.
 * The plasmodium tiles combine Ontoclasm's current Lair rock wall tiles
   and old ballistomycete spore trail tiles with CC0 scales by
   ARoachIFoundOnMyPillow.
 * The sporangium tile tweaks a spell icon by 7Soul1, and the launching
   spell icon adjusts the ballistomycete sporulation icon by aidanholm.
 * Vault distribution is very sparse, barring more tiles to help Slime
   vaults stand out at all versus the rest of the level.

New Slime monster: Slymdra (regret-index)

Combining the head mechanics famous on hydras (but used nowhere else) with
a variant of slime creature merging behaviors, these are terrifying melee
monsters for Slime.

They have acid-branded melee attacks and start with 4-5 heads, but can
passively absorb adjacent slime creatures to grow an additional head for
each one (and gain a bunch of HP in the process). Unlike normal slime
creatures, their constituant slimes will not passively split off from them
again while in combat, but if left wandering for a little while, will
gradually separate (meaning that fleeing from one that gets out of control
can still allow it to shrink back down again). Polymorphing one also spits
out any additional slime creatures it has absorbed.

Head mechanics operate almost identically to hydra; bladed weapons chop
heads and make new ones grow while flaming weapons can remove heads
altogether. Any new heads made this way will produce only unrewarding
slime creatures if separated (so no infinite slime creature farming).

They spawn with a small slime creature band (and the branch itself is full
of them), so attempting to position such that they absorb as few as
possible may be important - their corrosion inflicting melee obviously
scales non-linearly with how rapidly they can attack you!

-----------------------------

Slymdra vault distribution and tiles were done by regret-index.
 * The slymdra tiles combine ontoclasm's Hydra Form tile with roctavian's
   old soul eater and brown ooze tiles.
 * Vault distribution is limited to a slim number of Slime vaults looking
   for specific monsters, one Zot vault, variable Sprints, and Ziggurats.
   In the last of these, they replace scaling rockslime placement on Slime
   floors and scale additional heads with completed Zigs.

Don't merge unrewarding slime creatures with normal ones

They would just eat up the XP of the normal ones and never give it back
again.

Fix a habitability check for slime creature splitting/merging

This effectively considered slimes able to occupy lava, which could lead
to unneccessarily failed splits and messages about puffs of smoke.

Give Slime:$ unique glass tiles

The transparent walls that go down when killing The Royal Jelly (as of
2473c33) have unique names and descriptions loosely pointing at this
behaviour, but not a unique tile, which means most people won't ever
examine them to be hinted towards this behaviour. Giving them a new tile
can help both with this guidance and to establish more of a consistent
visual language for impending Slime Pit staircase changes.

Nudge up eyes of devastation

As monsters that only appear behind runed doors until post-Lair-branches,
and as monsters meant to help other Slime eyes actually successfully beat
lategame player Willpower, eyes of devastation can do with a bit of a
nudge up on raw numbers to actually stand out in their identity as the
only directly-attacking eye. (It can also help with Slime's third-rune
comparison issues.) As such, they are now speed 8 instead of speed 7,
do more damage with bolts of devastation, a fairly higher cast rate, a
a chance to come with a few golden eyes to guarantee Will/2 gets any use,
and a bit more AC- nothing overwhelming, but enough for it to even passably
compare to even other old monsters in other branches like various bolt
mages.

New monster: morphogenic oozes, for Slime

(Unlike the previous two, this doesn't really count as a revival of
something removed from Slime- in this case, pulsating lumps- even with
the most tenuous of connections.)

These morphogenic oozes are another rare high-tier threat meant to provide
variety for Slime. Such ichoate masses directly try to show something
otherwise quite absent in the current Slime opposition and instead
regulated to just Jiyva worship itself: the actual conversion of the
previous civilization into slime. As such, they have the new AF_SLIMIFY,
which isn't instant for players: each branded attack builds up 35 to 45
aut of a Slimifying status on living players, which when maxed out at
100 aut will turn one into the newly revived jelly form (for the polymorph
standard of 20 to 50 turns). This has the following effects:

 * Built-in jelly-emulating rPois, rCorr, acidic walls immunity,
   rBlind, SInv, and amorphous's rConstrict
 * All equipment but jewellery melded
 * AC scaling to a quarter of XL, +25% HP, and the same size and EV
 * Passable acidic unarmed melee scaling to XL
 * Double negative magic enhancers for all spells

(Most of these bonuses are present to help properly emulate current
innate jelly properties with some incidental defensive benefits in Slime
itself. On other fronts, jewellery not being melded is deliberate between
pseudopods reasonably matching up with octopode tentacles and there being
still branch resists a jelly can care about like Will+ and rC+ and rN+.
Since Dissolution can still invoke Jiyva, and with void oozes having had
their spell-affecting flooding effects heavily buffed this version, I
decided to experiment with negative enhancers like old shadow Form did as
hurting magic in a different fashion instead of fiddling with success
rates or turning off spells entirely.)

(UI-wise, this commit also adds red message highlighting for being
polymorphed or fully slimified, since it's as highly threatening as
other full disabling effects. With our very lacking badform look-up
available in-game, I've opted for a short parenthetical clipped to the
end of the description, which is somewhat unideal, but is also about as
much as is reasonable to handle in the scope of this version.)

While these are quite nasty for heavier armour characters and blasting
mages, these are still gentler effects than most other polymorph badforms
(which either disable movement or casting entirely, and which can turn off
even jewellery resists), and the build-up should give a reasonable amount
of recourse for people properly prioritizing them for such a threat. (For
the far-less-common case of living monsters being struck by this, I've
opted instead for a flat 1/4 chance for each hit to polymorph a monster
into the standard Slimify list. Since orc apostles have rPolymorph, this
will mostly just affect summoning spells weirdly.)

Like most high-tier slimes, these have high speed, decent health, and poor
AC, though they also get better EV than almost any other slime as a
notably fluctuating mass. They come in bands of 2 oozes plus 0-3 golden
eyes and great orbs of eyes- with the split ooze count trying to reduce
the pressure to make individual slimes have even higher numbers than the
current top-end slimes, and with the eyes trying to abuse the melding of
Will+ randart armour. They're rare enough there's only about a ~60% chance
to see one of their bands each Slime visit, and they're directly excluded
from Slime:5 + TRJ's spawn list (but not Jiyva's wrath!)- aside from
continuing to avoid making TRJ's fight more complicated, their flavour as
just-converted slimes also matches with colossal amoeba as working very
strangely inside TRJ itself.

The morphogenic ooze tile combines Denzi's old soul eaters, a piece for
a future spriggan wellspring by LemurRobot, and a rejected merged slime
creature tile by roctavian. The jellyform tile combines the current jelly
tile by Bloax with a CC0 slime sample by Henry Software.

Revive eyes of draining as rare deep negative energy eyes (DracoOmega)

Another significantly revised monster revival meant mostly to help with
more variety for a branch lacking in it. Eyes of draining were removed
in 049c24a for being harmless to magic-less builds, entirely harmless
without other enemies, and being too slow (at speed 5) to actually stick
to other enemies as they were otherwise supposed to spawn with. These
revived eyes of draining try to address all of these matters, while also
dealing with a weird bit of inconsistency in "Draining Gaze" having no
connection to other draining effects

 * These now have normal speed actions, M_CAUTIOUS, and fast movement.
   (Mostly, this means trying to walk away to keep them out of LOS is
    entirely unteneable without additional help.)

 * They now count as the leader for their band, so other monsters will
   follow them if they get ahead. (They also get somewhat customized
   bands in Slime, to always place a very-loosely-connected monster
   that actually deals damage to finish the player off.)

 * They lose their previous antimagic theming to serve as a serious rN
   check, with the new Draining Gaze doing no damage to instead directly
   drain for 10% of one's max health post-draining. (Following casts will
   drain 9%, then 8.1%, then 7.29%, and so on).

(While this does lead to them being harmless to those with full rN+++,
which several species get for free, this is hardly an unknown consequence
to Crawl- compare to how harmless death drakes are to the undead species
trio. rN is also no stranger to monsters that struggle to directly kill
players, as tormentors still functional well in doing. Slime also has
enough other prominent resist checks enough that a rare divergence to
value one of the currently least-valuable resists should be fine as an
occasional novelty of a threat.)

These spawn rarely in Slime, with an average low enough one appears in
only about 40% of all Slime visits: shining eyes already serve as plenty
of strategic damage, and giving Slime more variety also includes aiming for
some high-tier rare threats. They also spawn extremely rarely at the very
top end of the D out-of-depths pool, replacing the collective weight of
shadow dragons (similiar big rN check that should only spawn later with the
other top-tier dragons), war gargoyles, and iron dragons (both of which
have changes slated in the future to handle being placed so late that their
Metal Splinters almost never functions.) They also get some negative
energy theme placements in Ziggurats and Sprints, and one eye vault
placement in Depths.

(This commit also changes orange crystal statues, ghost moths, and Norris
to be casting "Antimagic Gaze" instead of "Draining Gaze", with adjusted
tile options between each of them. Hopefully, people won't confused about
this for too long- it's the more intuitive reading of Draining in a game
with so much draining costs and draining attacks, anyway.)

Their new tile and gaze vfx tweaks roctavian's edit of Denzi's old eye of
draining tile, while combining them with unused negative energy
projectiles also made by roctavian. The spell icon combines Denzi's
divinations eye with CanOfWorms's Powered By Death icons, and the
replacement Antimagic Gaze icon combines that eye with ontoclasm's Sap
Magic icon. This also adjusts the splash screen art by Peileppe and Bloax
to roughly approximate the monster's newer colours.

New(?) monster: colossal amoeba, for Slime

The overall enemy variety and unique enemy count for the Slime Pits are
severely low for a third rune branch in general, with 13 regular monsters
and a highly restrictive theme blocking off vaults from using much leaving
the branch lagging behind nearly every other full branch in the game. As
it has become more and more popular to take it as a third rune relative to
the branch falling behind buffs to players and Vaults alike, the branch
mostly being propped up on acid blobs and the one fixed fight of the Royal
Jelly becomes more conspicuously simple and flat compared to most other
branches having regular vaults and far more guests. As such, any new
monsters that can nudge up the difficulty and variety alike are reasonably
valuable, especially after the removal of five previous jellies and eyes
from the branch ended up with the branch deploying ~92 or so slime
creatures each game.

These colossal amoebae, blue 'J's in console, bare no real mechanical
resemblance to the giant amoebae removed back in cd953f7 for lacking any
unique mechanical identity. They instead have two flavourful attack brand
gimmicks: they undergo mitosis and cell division through the
self-summoning AF_SWARM of marrowcuda (0aa0afc), and that rapidly
expanding mass pulls in and consume foes through AF_DRAG (24261f8). They
have fairly high health (a bit above tentacled monstrosities, or on par
with three slime creatures) and demonic-crawler-level regeneration but
poor resists and defenses otherwise, and should be reasonably
straightforward and flavourful without particularly increasing Slime's
overall complexity- their weighting takes out a scaling fraction of slime
creature spawns (swapping ~5 amoeba for 14 of ~92 average slime
creatures), plus a tiny bit of azure jellies as are a little weak but
awkward to change with early ice cave use. Their play patterns are a
little weird- far less easy to destroy from afar than most of Slime and
less vulnerable to AOE compared to slime creatures, but also inherently
needing to pierce lategame player defences to actually start swarming and
dragging. (To this end, they have a small chance scaling with depth to
get a glowing orange brain or glass eye as organ support.) They should
still be novel enough, at least.

(Also, despite being sort of high-tier slimes in practice, these colossal
amoebae are notably not joining TRJ's or Jiyva's 5* Jelly expulsion spawn
selection, as they feel less pure slime than the current already-wide
selection- compare to how formless jellyfish didn't get into those lists
either.)

Their tile is a taller modification of ontoclasm's old giant amoeba tile.
Add another rumour to graffiti.

Fix mon_info unique name checks in a better way.

monster_info checks both type and base_type for monsters in many places,
so do that instead of manually specifying an exception for Tiamat.

Treat Tiamat as a name in monster_info again.

Since base_type is set differently for draconians with job classes, as
well as Tiamat, when we check whether the monster's base type is unique,
we need to check for Tiamat manually.

Fix crashing volcano triggers

This commit contains a fix for erroneous lua map marker behaviour seen
when hellmonk_volcano_collapse places as well as a fix to the event
dispatcher to prevent this behaviour from crashing the game. The first
fix will allow the map to create its markers properly when it places.
The second will prevent games from crashing where the map has generated
already with incorrect markers. I'll discuss both fixes more below.

Regarding the lua map maker behaviour, something odd is happening under
lua 5.4 with a closure that's used directly as a lua map marker. In
lm_trig.lua, the funciton Triggerable.synchronized_markers() creates a
closure with an upvalue `first` that initially true and supposed to be
set to false after the first call to the closure. After that, the
markers this function makes will be so-called "replica" property
markers. What's happening in practice is that modifications to `first`
aren't being retained by subsequent calls, so all markers being placed
are primary ones (i.e. TriggerrableFunction). Strangely, this problem
goes away if the lua state context is exited from the closure before
`first` is examined. That is, if I add calls to e.g. `crawl.mpr()` or to
the `io` library, subsequent calls to the closure see the updated
(false) value for `first`. My fix was to store the primary
initialization in the Triggerable table (keyed by replica id) rather
than updating an upvalue. But this should be considered a workaround, as
it's very concerning if closures/upvalues aren't behaving properly.

For the second fix to dgn_event_dispatcher, it seems that this class is
a bit naive in expecting the listeners in its internal list to be valid.
Since it fires off events to dlua that can execute arbitrary code, it's
certainly possible an arbitrary map marker in the dispatcher's list
might get removed (meaning it's an invalid listener object).
dgn_event_dispatcher::fire_event() already makes a copy of its listeners
before firing events because directly iterating over this list is unsafe
for the same reason. Since the copied list might contain a pointer to a
deleted map marker, I've added a method to verify that a listener is
actually in the master list. This is checked before attempting to fire
off a dungeon event on a listener.

Add dlua errors to crash dumps

Like how we do in the dlua_errors section of the morgue, print any dlua
errors. Do this before we print the back traces, since in a crash
scenario, this data is less volatile to access then the clua and dlua
states.
Add comments about possible name/word overlaps.
